Let me walk you through this comparison. We can use the benchmark at 1/2 to help us. First, look at 3/4 on the left bar. The shaded part goes past the 1/2 benchmark line, so 3/4 is greater than 1/2. Now look at 2/5 on the right bar. The shaded part stops before reaching the 1/2 benchmark, so 2/5 is less than 1/2. Since 3/4 is above 1/2 and 2/5 is below 1/2, that means 3/4 is greater than 2/5. The answer is >. That's how we use benchmarks to compare fractions - we compare each fraction to the benchmark, then use that to determine which is greater.
